column1: #Text=Airline bombing suspect spent months in Yemen
#Text=Authorities in Yemen say the Nigerian man accused of trying to destroy a U.S. airliner last week lived in Yemen during a four-month period earlier this year .
#Text=The Yemeni Foreign Ministry and it 's Minister , Abu Bakr al-Qirbi says 23-year-old Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab lived there between early August and early December .
#Text=The ministry says the Nigerian was granted a visa to study Arabic at an institute in the capital Sana'a .
#Text=Security officials say they approved the visa for Abdulmutallab because he was granted visas by several friendly countries , and still held a valid visa to the United States .
#Text=Abdulmutallab is charged with trying to detonate a bomb while flying aboard Northwest Airlines Flight 253 traveling from Amsterdam to Detroit .
#Text=Authorities say he unsuccessfully tried to set off explosives attached to his body as the plane was approaching Detroit .
#Text=A group known as al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula claimed responsibility on Monday for the failed attack .
#Text=In an Internet statement , the group says the attack was in retaliation for U.S. support for operations against the group in Yemen .
#Text=The claim could not be independently verified .

#Text=Yemen has recently begun operations with U.S. support against al-Qaeda due to concerns that the country is becoming a training ground for militants . al-Qirbi said to BBC 's Radio 4 , that al-Qeada remains a top priority despite the Yemeni government having to deal with two insurgencies , one in the north by Shi'a rebels and one in the south by separatists .
#Text=al-Qirbi said the Yemeni government needs more support , " We need more training .

#Text=He vowed to use every element of U.S. power  to disrupt , to dismantle and defeat " extremists in Afghanistan , Pakistan , Yemen , Somalia or elsewhere , who might want to attack the United States .

column1: #Text=Abdulmutallab 's name was listed in a U.S. government intelligence database , but he was not on the government 's so-called " no-fly list , " which would have banned him from flying on a U.S. airline .
#Text=His father , a prominent banker and former Nigerian government minister , had warned the U.S. embassy in Nigeria about his son 's extremist views .
